Ch2. Integration Theory

1. Given a collection of sets F1,F2,⋯ ,FnF_1, F_2, \cdots, F_nF1​,F2​,⋯,Fn​, construct another collection E1,E2,⋯ ,ENE_1, E_2, \cdots, E_NE1​,E2​,⋯,EN​ (N=2n−1)(N = 2^n - 1)(N=2n−1) so that Ei∩Ej=∅E_i \cap E_j = \varnothingEi​∩Ej​=∅ (i≠j)(i \neq j)(i=j), and Fk=⋃i∈IkEiF_k = \bigcup_{i \in I_k} E_iFk​=⋃i∈Ik​​Ei​.

proof

(1) construction of {Ei}i=1N\{E_i\}_{i=1}^N{Ei​}i=1N​

For i=1,2,…,2n−1i = 1, 2, \dots, 2^n - 1i=1,2,…,2n−1, write iii as an nnn-digit binary number :
i=(i^n,…,i^1)2i = (\hat{i}_n, \dots, \hat{i}_1)_2i=(i^n​,…,i^1​)2​

(ex) n=3⇒N=23−1=7⇒5=101(2)n = 3 \Rightarrow N = 2^3 - 1 = 7 \Rightarrow 5 = 101_{(2)}n=3⇒N=23−1=7⇒5=101(2)​
Next, for k=1,…,nk = 1, \dots, nk=1,…,n, let Gi,k=FkG_{i,k} = F_kGi,k​=Fk​ if i^k=1\hat{i}_k = 1i^k​=1 and Gi,k=FkcG_{i,k} = F_k^cGi,k​=Fkc​ if i^k=0\hat{i}_k = 0i^k​=0.
Then, let Ei=⋂k=1nGi,kE_i = \bigcap_{k=1}^n G_{i,k}Ei​=⋂k=1n​Gi,k​.
Note that there is at least one FkF_kFk​ such that Ei⊂FkE_i \subset F_kEi​⊂Fk​ (if not, Ei=⋂kFkcE_i = \bigcap_k F_k^cEi​=⋂k​Fkc​ so i^=0⇒\hat{i} = 0 \Rightarrowi^=0⇒ contradiction).

(2) EiE_iEi​, EjE_jEj​ are disjoint (i≠ji \neq ji=j)

If i≠ji \neq ji=j, so there is at least one digit in binary number such that i^k≠j^k\hat{i}_k \neq \hat{j}_ki^k​=j^​k​ (k=1,…,nk = 1, \dots, nk=1,…,n).
Let i^k=0\hat{i}_k = 0i^k​=0 and j^k=1\hat{j}_k = 1j^​k​=1 w.o.l.g. then
Ei⊂FkcE_i \subset F_k^cEi​⊂Fkc​ and Ej⊂FkE_j \subset F_kEj​⊂Fk​.
Each EiE_iEi​ and EjE_jEj​ are included in disjoint sets (Fkc,Fk)(F_k^c, F_k)(Fkc​,Fk​) respectively, so Ei∩Ej=∅E_i \cap E_j = \varnothingEi​∩Ej​=∅.

(3) Fk=⋃i:i^k=1EiF_k = \bigcup_{i: \hat{i}_k = 1} E_iFk​=⋃i:i^k​=1​Ei​ (k=1,…,nk = 1, \dots, nk=1,…,n)

Let the EiE_iEi​ included in FkF_kFk​ be denoted by EjkE_j^kEjk​ (j=1,…,2n−1j = 1, \dots, 2^{n-1}j=1,…,2n−1)

  1. ⇐\Leftarrow⇐
    Since Ejk⊂FkE_j^k \subset F_kEjk​⊂Fk​ for all jjj, ⋃jEjk⊂Fk\bigcup_j E_j^k \subset F_k⋃j​Ejk​⊂Fk​ (trivial)

  2. ⇒\Rightarrow⇒
    x∈Fkx \in F_kx∈Fk​
    Check whether x∈Eix \in E_ix∈Ei​ (1≤i≤2n−11 \le i \le 2^n - 11≤i≤2n−1), then x∈EI=⋂r=1nGI,rx \in E_I = \bigcap_{r=1}^n G_{I,r}x∈EI​=⋂r=1n​GI,r​ for some III.
    Since GI,k=FkG_{I,k} = F_kGI,k​=Fk​, EI⊂FkE_I \subset F_kEI​⊂Fk​ and EI=EjkE_I = E_j^kEI​=Ejk​ for some jjj.
    Thus, x∈⋃jEjkx \in \bigcup_j E_j^kx∈⋃j​Ejk​.

(4) ⋃k=1nFk=⋃i=1NEi\bigcup_{k=1}^n F_k = \bigcup_{i=1}^N E_i⋃k=1n​Fk​=⋃i=1N​Ei​

  1. ⇐\Leftarrow⇐
    x∈⋃iEix \in \bigcup_i E_ix∈⋃i​Ei​, then there exists I∈NI \in NI∈N such that x∈EIx \in E_Ix∈EI​ (1≤I≤N)(1 \le I \le N)(1≤I≤N).
    Then, there is K∈NK \in NK∈N such that 1≤K≤n1 \le K \le n1≤K≤n and EI⊂FKE_I \subset F_KEI​⊂FK​.
    So x∈FKx \in F_Kx∈FK​ and thus x∈⋃k=1nFkx \in \bigcup_{k=1}^n F_kx∈⋃k=1n​Fk​.

  2. ⇒\Rightarrow⇒
    y∈⋃k=1nFky \in \bigcup_{k=1}^n F_ky∈⋃k=1n​Fk​, so there exists K∈NK \in NK∈N such that y∈FKy \in F_Ky∈FK​.
    Due to (3), FKF_KFK​ can be written as ⋃i∈IKEi\bigcup_{i \in I_K} E_i⋃i∈IK​​Ei​.
    Then, y∈Eiy \in E_iy∈Ei​ for some iii (1≤i≤N)(1 \le i \le N)(1≤i≤N).
    This leads to y∈⋃i=1NEiy \in \bigcup_{i=1}^N E_iy∈⋃i=1N​Ei​.

(5) conclusion

The collection {Ei}i=1N\{E_i\}_{i=1}^N{Ei​}i=1N​ satisfies
Ei∩Ej=∅ (i≠j),Fk=⋃i∈IkEi,and⋃k=1nFk=⋃i=1NEi. E_i \cap E_j = \varnothing \ (i \ne j), \quad F_k = \bigcup_{i \in I_k} E_i, \quad \text{and} \quad \bigcup_{k=1}^n F_k = \bigcup_{i=1}^N E_i. Ei​∩Ej​=∅ (i=j),Fk​=i∈Ik​⋃​Ei​,andk=1⋃n​Fk​=i=1⋃N​Ei​.

2. If fff is integrable on Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd and δ>0\delta > 0δ>0, then show that ∥f(δx)−f(x)∥1→0\|f(\delta x) - f(x)\|_1 \to 0∥f(δx)−f(x)∥1​→0 as δ→1\delta \to 1δ→1. (Let F(x)=f(δx)F(x) = f(\delta x)F(x)=f(δx))

proof

(1) continuous function ggg of compact support

For given ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0, there is a continuous function ggg of compact support KKK such that ∥f−g∥1<ε\|f - g\|_1 < \varepsilon∥f−g∥1​<ε.
Using this function, f(δ)−ff^{(\delta)} - ff(δ)−f can be written as (f(δ)−g(δ))+(g(δ)−g)+(g−f)(f^{(\delta)} - g^{(\delta)}) + (g^{(\delta)} - g) + (g - f)(f(δ)−g(δ))+(g(δ)−g)+(g−f).
Then,
∥f(δ)−f∥1≤∥f(δ)−g(δ)∥1+∥g(δ)−g∥1+∥g−f∥1 \|f^{(\delta)} - f\|_1 \le \|f^{(\delta)} - g^{(\delta)}\|_1 + \|g^{(\delta)} - g\|_1 + \|g - f\|_1 ∥f(δ)−f∥1​≤∥f(δ)−g(δ)∥1​+∥g(δ)−g∥1​+∥g−f∥1​

(2) ∥f(δ)−g(δ)∥1\|f^{(\delta)} - g^{(\delta)}\|_1∥f(δ)−g(δ)∥1​

∥f(δx)−g(δx)∥1=δd∥f(x)−g(x)∥1 \|f(\delta x) - g(\delta x)\|_1 = \delta^d \|f(x) - g(x)\|_1 ∥f(δx)−g(δx)∥1​=δd∥f(x)−g(x)∥1​

δd\delta^dδd is a continuous real function, so there is β0>0\beta_0 > 0β0​>0 such that ∣δ−1∣<β0|\delta - 1| < \beta_0∣δ−1∣<β0​ implies δd<1\delta^d < 1δd<1.
For such δ\deltaδ, ∥f(δ)−g(δ)∥1<∥f−g∥1\|f^{(\delta)} - g^{(\delta)}\|_1 < \|f - g\|_1∥f(δ)−g(δ)∥1​<∥f−g∥1​.

(3) ∥g(δ)−g∥1\|g^{(\delta)} - g\|_1∥g(δ)−g∥1​

1) Continuous g(δ)g^{(\delta)}g(δ)

Let {xn}\{x_n\}{xn​} be a sequence in Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd such that lim⁡n→∞xn=x\lim_{n \to \infty} x_n = xlimn→∞​xn​=x.
ggg is continuous on KKK, so lim⁡n→∞g(xn)=g(x)\lim_{n \to \infty} g(x_n) = g(x)limn→∞​g(xn​)=g(x) by definition.
Then, lim⁡n→∞g(δ)(xn)=g(δ)(x)\lim_{n \to \infty} g^{(\delta)}(x_n) = g^{(\delta)}(x)limn→∞​g(δ)(xn​)=g(δ)(x) as well (PMA 4.2).
Note that ggg is supported on some BRB_RBR​, where K⊂BRK \subset B_RK⊂BR​.

2) g(δ)g^{(\delta)}g(δ) is supported on BDR‾\overline{B_{DR}}BDR​​

g(δ)(x)=g(δx)g^{(\delta)}(x) = g(\delta x)g(δ)(x)=g(δx) is continuous on a compact set 1δK⊂BR‾\frac{1}{\delta} K \subset \overline{B_R}δ1​K⊂BR​​.
Since 1δ→1\frac{1}{\delta} \to 1δ1​→1 as δ→1\delta \to 1δ→1, there is D>1D > 1D>1 such that ∣δ∣≤D|\delta| \le D∣δ∣≤D for all δ\deltaδ near 1.
Then, g(δ)g^{(\delta)}g(δ) is supported on D⋅BR‾=BDR‾D \cdot \overline{B_R} = \overline{B_{DR}}D⋅BR​​=BDR​​.

3) ∥gn−g∥1→0\|g_n - g\|_1 \to 0∥gn​−g∥1​→0

gng_ngn​ is a multiplication of measurable functions (g,χBRng, \chi_{B_{R_n}}g,χBRn​​​), so it is measurable.
∣gn∣≤∣g∣|g_n| \le |g|∣gn​∣≤∣g∣ and ggg is continuous on KKK, so ∃M>0\exists M > 0∃M>0 such that ∣g∣≤M|g| \le M∣g∣≤M and thus ∣gn∣≤M|g_n| \le M∣gn​∣≤M.
gng_ngn​ is supported on BR‾\overline{B_R}BR​​ with finite measure.
lim⁡n→∞gn=g \lim_{n \to \infty} g_n = g n→∞lim​gn​=g
Thus, lim⁡n→∞∥gn−g∥1=0\lim_{n \to \infty} \|g_n - g\|_1 = 0limn→∞​∥gn​−g∥1​=0 (BCT).

4) ∥g(δ)−g∥1→0\|g^{(\delta)} - g\|_1 \to 0∥g(δ)−g∥1​→0

lim⁡δ→1g(δ)=g\lim_{\delta \to 1} g^{(\delta)} = glimδ→1​g(δ)=g holds for all {xn}\{x_n\}{xn​} such that lim⁡n→∞δn=1\lim_{n \to \infty} \delta_n = 1limn→∞​δn​=1.
So, lim⁡δ→1∥g(δ)−g∥1=0\lim_{\delta \to 1} \|g^{(\delta)} - g\|_1 = 0limδ→1​∥g(δ)−g∥1​=0.
For given ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0, there is βε>0\beta_\varepsilon > 0βε​>0 s.t. ∣δ−1∣<βε|\delta - 1| < \beta_\varepsilon∣δ−1∣<βε​ implies ∥g(δ)−g∥1<ε\|g^{(\delta)} - g\|_1 < \varepsilon∥g(δ)−g∥1​<ε.

(4) lim⁡δ→1∥f(δ)−f∥1=0\lim_{\delta \to 1} \|f^{(\delta)} - f\|_1 = 0limδ→1​∥f(δ)−f∥1​=0, conclusion

Let β=min⁡(β0,βε)\beta = \min(\beta_0, \beta_\varepsilon)β=min(β0​,βε​).
Then,
∥f(δ)−f∥1≤∥f(δ)−g(δ)∥1+∥g(δ)−g∥1+∥f−g∥1<3εfor ∣δ−1∣<β, \|f^{(\delta)} - f\|_1 \le \|f^{(\delta)} - g^{(\delta)}\|_1 + \|g^{(\delta)} - g\|_1 + \|f - g\|_1 < 3\varepsilon \quad \text{for } |\delta - 1| < \beta, ∥f(δ)−f∥1​≤∥f(δ)−g(δ)∥1​+∥g(δ)−g∥1​+∥f−g∥1​<3εfor ∣δ−1∣<β,
and this holds for all ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0.
Thus,
lim⁡δ→1∥f(δ)−f∥1=0. \lim_{\delta \to 1} \|f^{(\delta)} - f\|_1 = 0. δ→1lim​∥f(δ)−f∥1​=0.

3. fff is integrable on [−π,π][-\pi, \pi][−π,π] and extended to R\mathbb{R}R by making it periodic of 2π2\pi2π. Then, show that ∫If(x) dx=∫−ππf(x) dx\int_I f(x)\,dx = \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} f(x)\,dx∫I​f(x)dx=∫−ππ​f(x)dx, where III is any interval of length 2π2\pi2π.

proof

(1)

∫02πf(x) dx−∫−ππf(x) dx={∫0πf(x) dx+∫π2πf(x) dx}−{∫−π0f(x) dx+∫0πf(x) dx}=∫π2πf(x) dx−∫−π0f(x) dx=∫0πf(x+π) dy−∫0πf(x) dx(x=T+y)=∫0πf(y) dy−∫0πf(x) dx=0\begin{align*} \int_0^{2\pi} f(x)\,dx - \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} f(x)\,dx &= \left\{ \int_0^{\pi} f(x)\,dx + \int_{\pi}^{2\pi} f(x)\,dx \right\} - \left\{ \int_{-\pi}^0 f(x)\,dx + \int_0^{\pi} f(x)\,dx \right\} \\ &= \int_{\pi}^{2\pi} f(x)\,dx - \int_{-\pi}^0 f(x)\,dx \\ &= \int_0^{\pi} f(x+\pi)\,dy - \int_0^{\pi} f(x)\,dx \quad (x = T + y) \\ &= \int_0^{\pi} f(y)\,dy - \int_0^{\pi} f(x)\,dx = 0 \end{align*}∫02π​f(x)dx−∫−ππ​f(x)dx​={∫0π​f(x)dx+∫π2π​f(x)dx}−{∫−π0​f(x)dx+∫0π​f(x)dx}=∫π2π​f(x)dx−∫−π0​f(x)dx=∫0π​f(x+π)dy−∫0π​f(x)dx(x=T+y)=∫0π​f(y)dy−∫0π​f(x)dx=0​

(2)

Let T=2πT = 2\piT=2π. Then
∫02πf(x) dx=∫aa+2πf(x) dx \int_0^{2\pi} f(x)\,dx = \int_a^{a+2\pi} f(x)\,dx ∫02π​f(x)dx=∫aa+2π​f(x)dx
for all a∈Ra \in \mathbb{R}a∈R, and in particular
∫02πf(x) dx=∫−ππf(x) dx(a=−π). \int_0^{2\pi} f(x)\,dx = \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} f(x)\,dx \quad (a = -\pi). ∫02π​f(x)dx=∫−ππ​f(x)dx(a=−π).
Thus,
∫If(x) dx=∫−ππf(x) dx \int_I f(x)\,dx = \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} f(x)\,dx ∫I​f(x)dx=∫−ππ​f(x)dx
for all intervals III with length 2π2\pi2π.

4. fff is integrable on [0,b][0,b][0,b] and g(x)=∫0xf(t) dtg(x) = \int_0^x f(t)\,dtg(x)=∫0x​f(t)dt (x∈(0,b])(x \in (0,b])(x∈(0,b]). Show that ggg is integrable on [0,b][0,b][0,b] and ∫0bg(x) dx=∫0bf(t)(b−t) dt\int_0^b g(x)\,dx = \int_0^b f(t)(b-t)\,dt∫0b​g(x)dx=∫0b​f(t)(b−t)dt.

proof

(1) h(t)=b−th(t) = b - th(t)=b−t is measurable (t>0)(t > 0)(t>0)

If a≤0a \le 0a≤0, {t∣h(t)<a}=∅\{t \mid h(t) < a\} = \varnothing{t∣h(t)<a}=∅.
If a>0a > 0a>0, {t∣h(t)<a}={t∈R:t>b−a}\{t \mid h(t) < a\} = \{t \in \mathbb{R} : t > b - a\}{t∣h(t)<a}={t∈R:t>b−a}, which is open and consequently measurable.
Since {t∣h(t)<a}\{t \mid h(t) < a\}{t∣h(t)<a} is a measurable set for all a∈Ra \in \mathbb{R}a∈R, hhh is a measurable function.

(2) ggg is integrable on [0,b][0,b][0,b]

∫0b∣g(x)∣ dx=∫0b∣∫0xf(t) dt∣dx≤∫0b∫0x∣f(t)∣ dt dx.\begin{align*} \int_0^b |g(x)|\,dx &= \int_0^b \left| \int_0^x f(t)\,dt \right| dx \le \int_0^b \int_0^x |f(t)|\,dt\,dx. \end{align*}∫0b​∣g(x)∣dx​=∫0b​∣∣​∫0x​f(t)dt∣∣​dx≤∫0b​∫0x​∣f(t)∣dtdx.​

h(x,t)=∣f(t)∣ χt<xh(x,t) = |f(t)| \, \chi_{t < x}h(x,t)=∣f(t)∣χt<x​ is measurable, and ∣f(t)∣|f(t)|∣f(t)∣ is measurable (since fff is measurable),
so the sequence of the last integral can be changed (Thm 2.3.2(iii)):

∫0b∫0x∣f(t)∣ dt dx=∫0b∫tb∣f(t)∣ dx dt=∫0b∣f(t)∣(b−t) dt<∞\begin{align*} \int_0^b \int_0^x |f(t)|\,dt\,dx &= \int_0^b \int_t^b |f(t)|\,dx\,dt = \int_0^b |f(t)|(b - t)\,dt < \infty \end{align*}∫0b​∫0x​∣f(t)∣dtdx​=∫0b​∫tb​∣f(t)∣dxdt=∫0b​∣f(t)∣(b−t)dt<∞​

(since fff is integrable).
Thus, ∫0b∣g(x)∣ dx<∞\int_0^b |g(x)|\,dx < \infty∫0b​∣g(x)∣dx<∞, so ggg is integrable on [0,b][0,b][0,b].

(3) conclusion

∫0bg(x) dx=∫0b∫0xf(t) dt dx(note that 0≤t≤x≤b)=∫0b∫tbf(t) dx dt(since f,h are measurable, Thm 2.3.2)=∫0bf(t)(b−t) dt.\begin{align*} \int_0^b g(x)\,dx &= \int_0^b \int_0^x f(t)\,dt\,dx \quad \text{(note that $0 \le t \le x \le b$)} \\ &= \int_0^b \int_t^b f(t)\,dx\,dt \quad (\text{since } f, h \text{ are measurable, Thm 2.3.2}) \\ &= \int_0^b f(t)(b - t)\,dt. \end{align*}∫0b​g(x)dx​=∫0b​∫0x​f(t)dtdx(note that 0≤t≤x≤b)=∫0b​∫tb​f(t)dxdt(since f,h are measurable, Thm 2.3.2)=∫0b​f(t)(b−t)dt.​

5. FFF is a closed set in R\mathbb{R}R, where m(F)<∞m(F) < \inftym(F)<∞. Let δ(x)=d(x,F)=inf⁡{∣x−z∣:z∈F}\delta(x) = d(x, F) = \inf\{|x - z| : z \in F\}δ(x)=d(x,F)=inf{∣x−z∣:z∈F}, and I(x)=∫Rδ(y)∣x−y∣2 dyI(x) = \int_{\mathbb{R}} \frac{\delta(y)}{|x - y|^2} \, dyI(x)=∫R​∣x−y∣2δ(y)​dy.

(a) Show that δ\deltaδ is continuous

proof

① ∣δ(x)−δ(y)∣≤∣x−y∣|\delta(x) - \delta(y)| \le |x - y|∣δ(x)−δ(y)∣≤∣x−y∣ for x,y∈Rx, y \in \mathbb{R}x,y∈R

For given η>0\eta > 0η>0, there is z∈Fz \in Fz∈F such that ∣x−z∣<δ(x)+η|x - z| < \delta(x) + \eta∣x−z∣<δ(x)+η (by definition of δ\deltaδ).
Then,
δ(x)≤∣x−z∣≤∣x−y∣+∣y−z∣<∣x−y∣+δ(y)+η. \delta(x) \le |x - z| \le |x - y| + |y - z| < |x - y| + \delta(y) + \eta. δ(x)≤∣x−z∣≤∣x−y∣+∣y−z∣<∣x−y∣+δ(y)+η.
So, δ(x)−δ(y)<∣x−y∣+η\delta(x) - \delta(y) < |x - y| + \etaδ(x)−δ(y)<∣x−y∣+η.
Switching xxx and yyy yields δ(y)−δ(x)<∣x−y∣+η\delta(y) - \delta(x) < |x - y| + \etaδ(y)−δ(x)<∣x−y∣+η.
Then, ∣δ(x)−δ(y)∣<∣x−y∣+η|\delta(x) - \delta(y)| < |x - y| + \eta∣δ(x)−δ(y)∣<∣x−y∣+η holds for all η>0\eta > 0η>0,
so ∣δ(x)−δ(y)∣≤∣x−y∣(x,y∈R)|\delta(x) - \delta(y)| \le |x - y| \quad (x, y \in \mathbb{R})∣δ(x)−δ(y)∣≤∣x−y∣(x,y∈R).

② δ\deltaδ is continuous

Then, for every ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0, ∣δ(x)−δ(y)∣<ε|\delta(x) - \delta(y)| < \varepsilon∣δ(x)−δ(y)∣<ε holds if ∣x−y∣<ε|x - y| < \varepsilon∣x−y∣<ε.
Thus, δ\deltaδ is (uniformly) continuous on R\mathbb{R}R.

(b) Show that I(x)=∞I(x) = \inftyI(x)=∞ for x∈Fcx \in F^cx∈Fc

proof

① δ(x)=2ε>0\delta(x) = 2\varepsilon > 0δ(x)=2ε>0

d(x,F)=0d(x, F) = 0d(x,F)=0 implies x∈F‾=Fx \in \overline{F} = Fx∈F=F.
So, d(x,F)>0d(x, F) > 0d(x,F)>0 if x∉Fx \notin Fx∈/F.
Let δ(x)=2ε>0\delta(x) = 2\varepsilon > 0δ(x)=2ε>0.

② δ(y)>ε\delta(y) > \varepsilonδ(y)>ε

Consider the interval ∣y−x∣<ε|y - x| < \varepsilon∣y−x∣<ε: x−ε<y<x+εx - \varepsilon < y < x + \varepsilonx−ε<y<x+ε.
This leads to ∣δ(y)−δ(x)∣<ε|\delta(y) - \delta(x)| < \varepsilon∣δ(y)−δ(x)∣<ε due to (a).
Then, δ(y)>δ(x)−ε=ε\delta(y) > \delta(x) - \varepsilon = \varepsilonδ(y)>δ(x)−ε=ε holds.

③ I(x)=∞I(x) = \inftyI(x)=∞, conclusion

Then,

∫0∞m(Eα)dα=∫0∞∫RdχEα(x)dx dα=∫Rd∫0∞χEα(x)dα dx(Tonelli’s thm)\begin{align*} \int_0^\infty m(E_\alpha) d\alpha &= \int_0^\infty \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} \chi_{E_\alpha}(x) dx \, d\alpha \\ &= \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} \int_0^\infty \chi_{E_\alpha}(x) d\alpha \, dx \quad (\text{Tonelli’s thm}) \end{align*}∫0∞​m(Eα​)dα​=∫0∞​∫Rd​χEα​​(x)dxdα=∫Rd​∫0∞​χEα​​(x)dαdx(Tonelli’s thm)​

③ Conclusion

For given x∈Rdx \in \mathbb{R}^dx∈Rd,
χEα(x)={1,0<α<∣f(x)∣,0,α≥∣f(x)∣. \chi_{E_\alpha}(x) = \begin{cases} 1, & 0 < \alpha < |f(x)|, \\ 0, & \alpha \ge |f(x)|. \end{cases} χEα​​(x)={1,0,​0<α<∣f(x)∣,α≥∣f(x)∣.​

(as a function of α\alphaα). Then,
∫0∞χEα(x)dα=∫0∣f(x)∣1 dα=∣f(x)∣. \int_0^\infty \chi_{E_\alpha}(x) d\alpha = \int_0^{|f(x)|} 1 \, d\alpha = |f(x)|. ∫0∞​χEα​​(x)dα=∫0∣f(x)∣​1dα=∣f(x)∣.

Thus,
∫0∞m(Eα)dα=∫Rd∣f(x)∣dx. \int_0^\infty m(E_\alpha) d\alpha = \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} |f(x)| dx. ∫0∞​m(Eα​)dα=∫Rd​∣f(x)∣dx.

21. fff and ggg are measurable functions on Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd.

(b) If fff and ggg are integrable on Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd, show that f(x−y)g(y)f(x - y) g(y)f(x−y)g(y) is integrable on R2d\mathbb{R}^{2d}R2d.

proof

f(x−y)g(y)f(x - y) g(y)f(x−y)g(y) is measurable on R2d\mathbb{R}^{2d}R2d, as well as ∣f(x−y)g(y)∣|f(x - y) g(y)|∣f(x−y)g(y)∣.
Then,

∬R2d∣f(x−y)g(y)∣ dy dx=∫Rd∫Rd∣f(x−y)∣∣g(y)∣ dy dx=∫Rd∣g(y)∣(∫Rd∣f(x−y)∣ dx)dy=∫Rd∣f(x)∣dx∫Rd∣g(y)∣dy<∞(∵f,g∈L1).\begin{align*} \iint_{\mathbb{R}^{2d}} |f(x - y) g(y)| \, dy \, dx &= \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} |f(x - y)| |g(y)| \, dy \, dx \\ &= \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} |g(y)| \left( \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} |f(x - y)| \, dx \right) dy \\ &= \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} |f(x)| dx \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} |g(y)| dy < \infty \quad (\because f, g \in L^1). \end{align*}∬R2d​∣f(x−y)g(y)∣dydx​=∫Rd​∫Rd​∣f(x−y)∣∣g(y)∣dydx=∫Rd​∣g(y)∣(∫Rd​∣f(x−y)∣dx)dy=∫Rd​∣f(x)∣dx∫Rd​∣g(y)∣dy<∞(∵f,g∈L1).​

Thus, f(x−y)g(y)f(x - y) g(y)f(x−y)g(y) is integrable.

© The convolution of f,g∈L1f, g \in L^1f,g∈L1 is defined as follows:(f∗g)(x)=∫Rdf(x−y)g(y) dy.(f * g)(x) = \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} f(x - y) g(y) \, dy.(f∗g)(x)=∫Rd​f(x−y)g(y)dy. Show that f(x−y)g(y)f(x - y) g(y)f(x−y)g(y) is integrable on Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd a.e. xxx.

proof

So, (f∗g)(x)=∫f(x−y)g(y)dy<∞(f * g)(x) = \int f(x - y) g(y) dy < \infty(f∗g)(x)=∫f(x−y)g(y)dy<∞ a.e. xxx,
and thus f(x−y)g(y)f(x - y) g(y)f(x−y)g(y) is integrable on Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd a.e. xxx.

(d)-1 Show that f∗gf * gf∗g is integrable on Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd when f,gf, gf,g are integrable:

∥f∗g∥1≤∥f∥1 ∥g∥1. \| f * g \|_1 \le \| f \|_1 \, \| g \|_1. ∥f∗g∥1​≤∥f∥1​∥g∥1​.

proof

∫∣(f∗g)(x)∣dx≤∫Rd∫Rd∣f(x−y)g(y)∣ dy dx=∫Rd∣f(x−y)∣dx ∣g(y)∣dy=∥f∥1 ∥g∥1<∞.\begin{align*} \int |(f * g)(x)| dx &\le \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} |f(x - y) g(y)| \, dy \, dx \\ &= \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} |f(x - y)| dx \, |g(y)| dy = \| f \|_1 \, \| g \|_1 < \infty. \end{align*}∫∣(f∗g)(x)∣dx​≤∫Rd​∫Rd​∣f(x−y)g(y)∣dydx=∫Rd​∣f(x−y)∣dx∣g(y)∣dy=∥f∥1​∥g∥1​<∞.​

proof

becomes an equality when f(x−y)g(y)f(x - y) g(y)f(x−y)g(y) is non-negative (Thm 2.1.11 (iv)).

24. Consider the convolution (f∗g)(x)=∫Rdf(x+y)g(y) dy(x∈Rd)(f * g)(x) = \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} f(x + y) g(y) \, dy \quad (x \in \mathbb{R}^d)(f∗g)(x)=∫Rd​f(x+y)g(y)dy(x∈Rd)

(a) Show that f∗gf * gf∗g is uniformly continuous when ∥f∥1<∞\| f \|_1 < \infty∥f∥1​<∞ and ∣g∣≤M|g| \le M∣g∣≤M (bounded).

proof

① f(x+y)g(y)f(x + y) g(y)f(x+y)g(y) is integrable

∫Rd∣f(x+y)g(y)∣dy≤M∫Rd∣f(x+y)∣dy=M∫Rd∣f(y)∣dy=M∥f∥1<∞. \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} |f(x + y) g(y)| dy \le M \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} |f(x + y)| dy = M \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} |f(y)| dy = M \| f \|_1 < \infty. ∫Rd​∣f(x+y)g(y)∣dy≤M∫Rd​∣f(x+y)∣dy=M∫Rd​∣f(y)∣dy=M∥f∥1​<∞.

② ∣(f∗g)(x)−(f∗g)(x′)∣≤M∥fx′−f∥1|(f * g)(x) - (f * g)(x')| \le M \| f_{x'} - f \|_1∣(f∗g)(x)−(f∗g)(x′)∣≤M∥fx′​−f∥1​

For x,x′∈Rdx, x' \in \mathbb{R}^dx,x′∈Rd,

∣(f∗g)(x)−(f∗g)(x′)∣=∣∫Rdf(x+y)g(y)dy−∫Rdf(x′+y)g(y)dy∣=∣∫Rd(f(x+y)−f(x′+y))g(y)dy∣≤∫Rd∣f(x+y)−f(x′+y)∣∣g(y)∣dy≤M∫Rd∣f(x+y)−f(x′+y)∣dy(∵∣g∣≤M)=M∫Rd∣f(y)−f(y−(x−x′))∣dy(translation invariance)=M∫Rd∣f(y)−f(y−(x−x′))∣dy(relative invariance, p.13)\begin{align*} |(f * g)(x) - (f * g)(x')| &= \left| \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} f(x + y) g(y) dy - \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} f(x' + y) g(y) dy \right| \\ &= \left| \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} (f(x + y) - f(x' + y)) g(y) dy \right| \\ &\le \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} |f(x + y) - f(x' + y)| |g(y)| dy \\ &\le M \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} |f(x + y) - f(x' + y)| dy \quad (\because |g| \le M) \\ &= M \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} |f(y) - f(y - (x - x'))| dy \quad (\text{translation invariance}) \\ &= M \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} |f(y) - f(y - (x - x'))| dy \quad (\text{relative invariance, p.13}) \end{align*}∣(f∗g)(x)−(f∗g)(x′)∣​=∣∣​∫Rd​f(x+y)g(y)dy−∫Rd​f(x′+y)g(y)dy∣∣​=∣∣​∫Rd​(f(x+y)−f(x′+y))g(y)dy∣∣​≤∫Rd​∣f(x+y)−f(x′+y)∣∣g(y)∣dy≤M∫Rd​∣f(x+y)−f(x′+y)∣dy(∵∣g∣≤M)=M∫Rd​∣f(y)−f(y−(x−x′))∣dy(translation invariance)=M∫Rd​∣f(y)−f(y−(x−x′))∣dy(relative invariance, p.13)​

③ Conclusion

For given ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0, there is δ0>0\delta_0 > 0δ0​>0 such that
∣x−x′∣<δ0|x - x'| < \delta_0∣x−x′∣<δ0​ implies ∥fx−x′−f∥1=∫Rd∣f(y−(x−x′))−f(y)∣dy<ε/M\| f_{x - x'} - f \|_1 = \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} |f(y - (x - x')) - f(y)| dy < \varepsilon / M∥fx−x′​−f∥1​=∫Rd​∣f(y−(x−x′))−f(y)∣dy<ε/M
(∵f∈L1\because f \in L^1∵f∈L1, Prop 2.2.5).

Then, ∣x−x′∣<δ0|x - x'| < \delta_0∣x−x′∣<δ0​ means ∣(f∗g)(x)−(f∗g)(x′)∣<Mε|(f * g)(x) - (f * g)(x')| < M \varepsilon∣(f∗g)(x)−(f∗g)(x′)∣<Mε.
This holds for all ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0, so f∗gf * gf∗g is uniformly continuous.

(b) If ggg is integrable as well, show that lim⁡∣x∣→∞(f∗g)(x)=0\lim_{|x| \to \infty} (f * g)(x) = 0lim∣x∣→∞​(f∗g)(x)=0

proof

For given ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0, there is a simple function fεf_\varepsilonfε​ and gεg_\varepsilongε​ such that
∥f−fε∥<ε4∥g∥1\| f - f_\varepsilon \| < \frac{\varepsilon}{4 \| g \|_1}∥f−fε​∥<4∥g∥1​ε​ and ∥g−gε∥<ε4∥fε∥1\| g - g_\varepsilon \| < \frac{\varepsilon}{4 \| f_\varepsilon \|_1}∥g−gε​∥<4∥fε​∥1​ε​.

Then,

∣(f∗g)(x)∣=∣∫Rdf(x−y)g(y)dy∣≤∫Rd∣f(x−y)−fε(x−y)∣∣g(y)∣dy+∫Rd∣fε(x−y)∣∣g(y)−gε(y)∣dy+∫Rd∣fε(x−y)gε(y)∣dy≤∥f−fε∥1∥g∥1+∥fε∥1∥g−gε∥1+∫Rd∣fε(x−y)gε(y)∣dy.\begin{align*} |(f * g)(x)| &= \left| \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} f(x - y) g(y) dy \right| \\ &\le \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} |f(x - y) - f_\varepsilon(x - y)| |g(y)| dy + \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} |f_\varepsilon(x - y)| |g(y) - g_\varepsilon(y)| dy + \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} |f_\varepsilon(x - y) g_\varepsilon(y)| dy \\ &\le \| f - f_\varepsilon \|_1 \| g \|_1 + \| f_\varepsilon \|_1 \| g - g_\varepsilon \|_1 + \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} |f_\varepsilon(x - y) g_\varepsilon(y)| dy. \end{align*}∣(f∗g)(x)∣​=∣∣​∫Rd​f(x−y)g(y)dy∣∣​≤∫Rd​∣f(x−y)−fε​(x−y)∣∣g(y)∣dy+∫Rd​∣fε​(x−y)∣∣g(y)−gε​(y)∣dy+∫Rd​∣fε​(x−y)gε​(y)∣dy≤∥f−fε​∥1​∥g∥1​+∥fε​∥1​∥g−gε​∥1​+∫Rd​∣fε​(x−y)gε​(y)∣dy.​

Since a simple function is integrable and has compact support (Prop 2.21 (d)),
the last term ∫∣fε(x−y)gε(y)∣dy→0\int |f_\varepsilon(x - y) g_\varepsilon(y)| dy \to 0∫∣fε​(x−y)gε​(y)∣dy→0 as ∣x∣→∞|x| \to \infty∣x∣→∞ (by density argument).

Thus,
lim⁡∣x∣→∞(f∗g)(x)=0. \lim_{|x| \to \infty} (f * g)(x) = 0. ∣x∣→∞lim​(f∗g)(x)=0.

②

∣x−y∣≥∣x∣−∣y∣|x - y| \ge |x| - |y|∣x−y∣≥∣x∣−∣y∣, so lim⁡∣x∣→∞∣x−y∣=∞\lim_{|x| \to \infty} |x - y| = \inftylim∣x∣→∞​∣x−y∣=∞.
The simple function fεf_\varepsilonfε​ is supported on a set of finite measure,
lim⁡∣x∣→∞fε(x−y)=0\lim_{|x| \to \infty} f_\varepsilon(x - y) = 0lim∣x∣→∞​fε​(x−y)=0.
So,
lim⁡∣x∣→∞∫Rd∣fε(x−y)gε(y)∣dy=0. \lim_{|x| \to \infty} \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} |f_\varepsilon(x - y) g_\varepsilon(y)| dy = 0. ∣x∣→∞lim​∫Rd​∣fε​(x−y)gε​(y)∣dy=0.

③

Then,
lim⁡∣x∣→∞∣(f∗g)(x)∣≤∥f−fε∥1∥g∥1+∥fε∥1∥g−gε∥1<2ε, \lim_{|x| \to \infty} |(f * g)(x)| \le \| f - f_\varepsilon \|_1 \| g \|_1 + \| f_\varepsilon \|_1 \| g - g_\varepsilon \|_1 < 2 \varepsilon, ∣x∣→∞lim​∣(f∗g)(x)∣≤∥f−fε​∥1​∥g∥1​+∥fε​∥1​∥g−gε​∥1​<2ε,
and this holds for all ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0. Thus,
lim⁡∣x∣→∞(f∗g)(x)=0. \lim_{|x| \to \infty} (f * g)(x) = 0. ∣x∣→∞lim​(f∗g)(x)=0.
